SourceString: The alpha value. How quickly the reinforcement learning agent will learn.
Should the target be immune to damage when spawned? It can be removed later when activated.
The gamemode to base the custom game mode off of. For example, if you want targets in a grid, this needs to be set to BeatGrid.
If checked, the speed of the target will remain constant throughout the game mode.
How to change the vertical and horizontal spread of the spawn area, or not at all.
The vertical and horizontal spread of the spawn area grow larget based on consecutive targets hit.
The vertical and horizontal spread of the spawn area will not change.
How much to shrink the target after being deactivated. This number is multiplied by the target's scale prior to the target deactivating.
How to change the target scale between consecutive targets, or not at all.
The starting scale/size of the target will be chosen randomly between min and max target scale.
The starting scale/size of the target will gradually shrink from max to min target scale, based on consecutive targets hit.
The starting scale/size of the target will remain constant throughout the game mode.
Should targets always be allowed to activate or should only one target be activated at once?
Should targets always be allowed to spawn or should only one target be spawned at once?
The name to save your custom game mode as.
If checked, the game will spawn targets according to reinforcment learning algorithms. This should expose you to your weaknesses more often.
The epsilon value. A value of 1 will result in only choosing random values (explore), while a value of zero will result in only choosing locations where your accuracy is lowest.
Amount of health to take away from the target if the DamageableWindow timer expires. A hit target takes 100 damage by default.
Distance from floor to bottom of the spawn area.
If checked, the targets will move forward towards the player by ForwardDistance over the maximum target lifespan.
How far targets will move forward towards the player over the maximum target lifespan.
Useful for seeing what settings the default game modes use, but custom game modes have no difficulty by default.
See what settings the default game modes use to fine tune your custom game mode.
The gamma value. How much to value future rewards vs immediate rewards
Horizontal Spacing to <=
Number of Horizontal Targets <=
Number of Vertical Targets to <=
Maximum Target Scale to <=
Not enough space! Change one or more of the following:
Vertical Spacing to <=
By default, adjacent-only will only activate a target that was adjacent/beside a previously activated target. Completely random will choose a target in the grid at random.
Evenly distributes the targets so that the horizontal and vertical distance between targets is the same.
The number of targets that are spawned at the beginning.
How long the target will live, even if not shot. This doesn't apply to BeatTrack.
How to change the scale of the target over its lifetime, or not at all.
Change the target scale from its current to its maximum scale over its lifetime.
The scale of the target will not change over its lifetime.
Change the target scale from its current to its minimum scale over its lifetime.
Max health of the target. Hit targets take 100 damage, so increase this value if you want targets to survive more than one hit.
How many recent targets to keep in memory, if using Num Targets Based RecentMemoryPolicy.
The minimum distance between the edges of targets. Choosing a high value can cause the game to skip target spawns if it doesn't find room for it.
Whether or not the targets ever move.
How many charges or lives each target has before fully dissipating.
How many targets to spawn before the game mode begins.
If checked, the audio from the Input Audio Device will playback to the Output Audio Device. Check  this box if you aren't routing your Input Audio Device to your desktop sound.
Determines when to remove targets from recent memory, allowing targets to spawn in that location again.
Uses a specified time to remove recent targets, starting after the target has been destroyed or deactivated.
Does not remember any recent targets.
Removes recent targets only when the number of recent targets exceeds specified capacity.
Removes a recent target after TargetSpawnCD length of time has passed since the target has been destroyed or deactivated.
Length of time to keep targets flags as recent, if using Custom Time Based RecentMemoryPolicy.
Whether or not to spawn at the origin (center) if it isn't blocked by a recent target whenever possible.
Time between initial spawning of the target (white) and the beat (bright green). This is basically anticipated reaction time.
Whether or not spawn every other target at the origin (center).
What does the target do when its activated: change directions, make damageable, etc.
Immunity is granted to the target.
If a moving target, the direction is changed.
The scale is set according to ConsecutiveTargetScale. LifetimeTargetScale can still override this.
If a moving target, the velocity of the target is changed.
Immunity is removed from the target, damageable window begins if not already damageable.
Immunity is added or removed from the target, depending on its existing state. Same with damageable window.
How to choose the target(s) to activate.
Only choose spawn points that border the previous point (BeatGrid is an example).
Randomly chooses a target within the available spawn points.
How the player damages the target and receives score.
Firing the gun and hitting the target damages the target and awards score.
Having the CrossHair over the target damages the target and awards score.
Each represents one way that a target can be deactivated
Target is deactivated when it receives any damage from the player.
Target is deactivated after its damageable window closes.
Target is deactivated after its health reaches zero.
Targets are never deactivated, even if their health reaches zero.
What does the target do when its deactivated?
Immunity is granted to the target.
If a moving target, the direction is changed.
Sets the target scale to its current scale multiplied by "Deactivated Target Scale Multiplier".
If a moving target, the velocity of the target is changed.
Destroy the target permanently.
Temporarily hide the target until reactivated. Useful for hiding targets in modes that spawn targets upfront.
Play an explosion effect.
Immunity is removed from the target, damageable window begins if not already damageable.
Reset the color of the target to the inactive color.
Reset the color of the target to the inactive color.
Resets the target position back to the position it was activated at. Useful for moving targets.
Reset the scale of the target to the scale it was activated with.
Shrinks the target and slowly returns it to the scale it was activated with. Used in BeatGrid.
Immunity is added or removed from the target, depending on its existing state. Same with damageable window.
Each represents one way that a target can be destroyed.
Target is destroyed when it receives any damage from the player.
Target is destroyed when any of its deactivation conditions are met. This essentially makes any deactivation condition a destruction condition.
Target is deactivated after its damageable window closes.
Target is destroyed when its health reaches zero.
Targets are never destroyed, even if their health reaches zero. Can still be reactivated/deactivated.
How Targets are distributed in the spawn box.
Only spawn targets on the edges of the current spawn area.
Spawn targets anywhere in the current spawn area.
Spawns targets in an evenly-spaced grid. Targets spawn in the same locations within the grid.
The targests will only spawn at headshot height.
Sets the minimum time between target spawns. This doesn't guarantee a target will spawn at this rate, only that it is possible if there are beats.
When to spawn the targets.
Spawn targets when the TargetManager receives the signal from AudioAnalyzer.
Spawn all the targets before the game mode starts.
Minimum number of targets to activate at one time, if there's more than one target available to activate.
Maximum number of targets to activate at one time, if there's more than one target available to activate.
Number of targets to spawn at one time, during a game mode.
Maximum number of targets allowed to be activated at one time.
Maximum number of visible targets allowed at one time, regardless of activation state.
Which direction(s) to move targets.
Restrict target movement to only horizontal.
Restrict target movement to only vertical.
Restrict target movement to only horizontal and vertical, alternating between the two.
Move targets in any direction.
The horizontal spacing between targets (from edge to edge)
The vertical spacing between targets (from edge to edge)
The width of the area where targets can spawn. Maximum width if using Dynamic Bounds Scaling.
The height of the area where targets can spawn. Maximum height if using Dynamic Bounds Scaling.
The minimum size of a target. Affects other settings that depend on target scale.
The maximum size of a target. Affects other settings that depend on target scale.
The minimum speed of a moving target. Targets must have "Change Direction" or "Change Velocity" set as a Target Activation or Deactivation Response to actually move.
The maximum speed of a moving target. Targets must have "Change Direction" or "Change Velocity" set as a Target Activation or Deactivation Response to actually move.
The number of horizontal and vertical grid targets must be in increments of 5 for AI to properly function.
If checked, targets will not be spawned until the previous batch of targets have all been activated and deactivated.

If checked, allows targets to be spawned without immediate activation. If used in combination with Batch Spawning, this can allow multiple targets to spawn at once while each is activated according to Target Activation settings.
Low Latency mode is disabled.
Low Latency mode is enabled and optimizing system latency.
Low Latency mode is enabled and optimizing system latency. In Boost mode, NVIDIA Reflex will attempt to optimize latency in CPU bound cases as well. This can slightly increase GPU power draw.
Turns DLSS Super Resolution Off.
Offers higher image quality, but sacrificies performance.
Offers higher image quality than balanced mode.
Offers both optimized performance and image quality.
Offers a higher performance boost than balanced mode.
Offers the highest performance boost. Recommended for 8K gameplay only.
Selects the best DLSS Mode for the current output resolution.
AI-based anti-aliasing mode that uses the native resolution image to maximize image quality instead of boosting performance.
Turns DLSS Frame Generation off.
Generates an additional frame for each rendered frame.
NVIDIA DLSS uses AI to boost frame rates while maintaining image quality and responsiveness. This feature requires a GeForce RTX graphics card.
Frame Generation boosts frame rates by using AI to render additional frames. This features requires a GeForce RTX 40 Series graphics card.
Super Resolution boosts frame rates by rendering fewer pixels and using AI to output high resolution frames. This feature requires a GeForce RTX graphics card.
NVIDIA Reflex reduces system latency and increases PC responsiveness.
NVIDIA Image Scaling boosts frame rates using GPU scaling and sharpening.
